case_title: C. I.R., L.T.U., Islamabad vs Messrs Haseeb Estate Builders, Islamabad

accussed_details.name: Messrs Haseeb Estate Builders
allegation: Unexplained credit transactions in bank accounts

complaint_summary: The appellant alleged suppressed receipts and unexplained credit transactions in the respondent's bank accounts amounting to Rs.168,154,163 for the tax year 2004.
investigation_summary: The Assessing Officer treated credit transactions in three bank accounts as suppressed receipts without corroborative evidence. The taxpayer provided reconciliation statements and supporting documents to justify the transactions.
judgment_summary: The appellate tribunal upheld the decision of CIR(A-I), Islamabad, vacating the order of the Assessing Officer. The tribunal found no definite information to support the allegations of suppressed receipts and deemed the assessment flawed.
legal_arguments: No definite information provided by the Assessing Officer as required under section 122(5) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001.
The taxpayer's reconciliation statements and supporting evidence were deemed satisfactory.
The Assessing Officer relied on presumptive calculations without proving the nexus between credit entries and business receipts.
CIR(A) was not justified to admit new evidence under section 128(5) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001.
CIR(A) did not provide cogent reasons for vacating the Assessing Officer's order.
key_issues: Whether the credit transactions in the taxpayer's bank accounts constitute suppressed receipts.
Whether the Assessing Officer provided definite information to justify the amendment of the assessment order.

legal_terms.Suppressed receipts: Income or transactions not disclosed or misrepresented in tax filings.
legal_terms.Definite information: Concrete evidence required to amend an assessment under tax law.

words_and_phrases.Fishing inquiries: Investigative actions lacking specific evidence or direction.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around allegations of suppressed receipts in the taxpayer's bank accounts. The appellate tribunal upheld the CIR(A-I)'s decision to vacate the assessment order due to lack of definite information and reliance on presumptive calculations by the Assessing Officer.

appeal_observations.CIR(A) decision: Deleted addition of Rs.168,154,163 as suppressed receipts.
appeal_observations.reasoning: No definite information provided by the Assessing Officer to justify the addition.
appeal_observations.departmental_appeal: Considered of no merit and rejected.

assessment_flaws: No nexus established between credit entries and business receipts.
Open-ended assessment based on presumptive basis.
Fishing inquiries made without definite information.
